page.title: 03MEDICAL CARE IN RIPPINGALE
page.content: On the retirement of the previous general practitioner,who had a surgery attached to his house,a{lock-up {surgery}was built in 1968.This is in use each weekday and,because of its rural location,prescriptions are dispensed on the premises _ an unusual asset these days.A District Nurse/mid_ wife was still resident in Rippingale in the late 1970's.Following the axeing of this post,these services are now supplied by nurses,midwives and health visitors attached to the nearby Health Centre.More recently,the Infant Welfare Clinic closed and most of the immunisations are now done at the surgery whilst baby foods are bought at the village store. We are served by hospitals at Stamford,Boston,Grantham and Peterborough, ambulances are for emergencies only,so{Rippingale runs {its own hospital car service.
